#Text=Ubeda
#Text=Compact and walkable , the small city of Úbeda can be found just off the main Andalusian tourist trail at the center of Spain 's Jaén province .
#Text=As a refreshing change , Moorish heritage is not the main draw here ; it 's the fantastic collection of Italian-inspired Renaissance era palaces and churches .
#Text=Understand

#Text=These myriad graceful hills have likely settled since at least Roman times , although the town of Úbeda would n't come to be known as such until the rule of the Emir Abd ar-Rahman II ( 822 – 852 ) .
#Text=The town would be ruled by the Moors for centuries , until falling into Christian hands during the Reconquista , in 1233 .
#Text=After years of internecine squabbling between minor nobles , Christian Monarchs Isabella and Ferdinand feared that they would soon turn against one another .
#Text=The fortifications of the Alcázar were commanded to be pulled down in order to stimulate cooperation between the rival factions .
#Text=This — perhaps along with small quality of life improvements for the peasants — seems to have done the trick .
#Text=At the dawn of the 16th century , the relative peace and Úbeda 's fortuitous location allowed them to prosper through trade .
#Text=The towns fortunes improved again when emperor Charles V married into a local family , spurring a rash of construction .
#Text=Many of the fine buildings in town today date from this time .
#Text=Eventually the political spotlight turned elsewhere .
#Text=Over the years a series of natural disasters and wars took their toll on the local economy , and the town was brought to its lowest point .
#Text=As the 20th century rolled on , agricultural improvements allowed more olives to be grown .
#Text=Today tourism and cultural events are the newest additions to Úbeda 's growing repertoire .
#Text=Tourist Information Office , 5 Plaza de Andalucia , ☏ +34953779204 .
#Text=9AM-5PM daily .
#Text=Adjacent to the clocktower , the staff in this little office speak English and have plenty of fine maps and advice to dole out on whatever it is you 're interested in seeing .
#Text=Get in
#Text=With the closest train station being in Linares and airports being hundreds of miles away , your best bet is going to involve four weels .
#Text=By bus
#Text=Úbeda has a great , if small , bus station .
#Text=Dozens of busses shuttle back and forth to nearby Jaén ( € 6 , 1h ) daily , while there are also frequent connections with Granada ( € 8-13 , 2 h30m ) and other points to the south .
#Text=You 'll also find a few busses serving Cordoba ( € 7-13 , 2 h30m ) and points north .
#Text=A dozen or so lockers are available on-premises for 24-hour rental for about € 4 .
#Text=By car
#Text=The A-32 from Linares , and the A-316 from Jaén will both run you into town .
#Text=If you 're headed instead from far away Albacete , the N-322 will be the road for you .
#Text=All roads are quite well maintained and easy to navigate .
#Text=Get around
#Text=Seeing the sights in town is an activity best undertaken on foot .
#Text=The bus station is about a mile from the center ; however , so consider cabbing it to your hotel when you first arrive .
#Text=This will of course depend entirely on your own personal luggage weight to back strength calculus .
#Text=See
#Text=The dozens of magnificent Renaissance era buildings here were designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 2003 , and by far and away the reason most folks stop by .
#Text=If possible , avoid visiting Úbeda on Mondays , when many sites are closed or have reduced hours .
#Text=While all facades have been preserved , few interiors remain in their original 16th century state .
#Text=They 've often been turned into municipal buildings , or stately hotels for the well heeled .
#Text=Either way , they 're beautiful .
#Text=It 's easy to let your imagination run wild as you get lost rambling through the narrow streets of the old city .
#Text=Murallas de la Ciudad , Redonda de Miradores .
#Text=24 hours daily .
#Text=Circling the city , these walls were first built around the 10th century , and have been extensively modified over the years .
#Text=Various doors and watchtowers puncture the barricades and peak out atop the bulwarks .
#Text=The scenic loop in the southeastern quadrant of the city affords particularly spectacular views of the surrounding countryside and its olive-laden hills .
#Text=Free .
#Text=Palacio de Juan Vázquez de Molina ( Palacio de las Cadenas ) , Plaza Vázquez de Molina , ☏ +34953750440 .
#Text=M - F 8AM-8PM Sa 10AM-2PM / 4PM-8:30PM Su 10AM-2PM .
#Text=Considered to be one of the best examples of Renaissance architecture in Spain , the palace was built between 1546 and 1565 .
#Text=Architect Andrés de Vandelvira designed this palace as a Roman house , creating its entire structure around a large courtyard with a fountain in its center .
#Text=The main facade is very well proportioned and quite beautiful .
#Text=This has been Úbeda 's town hall since at least 1850 .
#Text=Free .
#Text=Parroquia de San Pablo , ☏ +34953750637 .
#Text=Tu - Sa 11AM-1PM / 6PM-8PM Su 11AM-1PM .
#Text=One of the oldest in Úbeda , this church is believed to have been built some time during the 13th century .
#Text=Its location in a central square and its proximity to the old town hall , made it the perfect choice for city council meetings throughout the 15th century .
#Text=In the early 16th century , the building was embellished with Renaissance details under Alonso Suárez de la Fuente , who carried out extensive renovations and enlargements .
#Text=Free .
#Text=Sacra Capilla del Salvador del Mundo , Plaza Vázquez de Molina , ☏ +34609279905 .
#Text=M - Sa 9:30AM-2:30PM / 4PM-6PM Su 11:30AM-3PM / 4PM-7PM .
#Text=Built between 1536-1559 under the patronage of Francisco de los Cobos .
#Text=Initially conceived as a funerary monument , it was re-envisioned while under construction to elevate the patron 's fame , fortune , and personal glory .
#Text=The complex sculptural decoration of both the main facade and interior contrast boldly with the austerity of the Palacio de Molina , on display just down the road .
#Text=The chapel 's grandiose circular centralized crypt is meant to expresses a unity with , and the infinite essence of , God . € 5 including audioguide , children € 2.50 .
#Text=Do
#Text=Hospital of Santiago , 28
#Text=Calle Obispo Cobos , ☏ +34953750842 .
#Text=This massive space was built around 1562-1575 , and spans an entire city block .
#Text=It 's since been completely renovated and now houses a massive event space as well as a library .
#Text=Work by new and established artists adorns the walls and rotates often .
#Text=Check their calendar for information about upcoming live performances .
#Text=Free .
